Also gives cause of depopulation.</ref> |cause=E |curlocl=[[Shomera]], [[Even Menachem]], [[Zar'it]], [[Shtula]] |pushpin_map=Mandatory Palestine }} '''Al-Nabi Rubin''' {{lang-ar|النبي روبين}} was a [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] village located 28 kilometers northeast of [[Acre, Israel|Acre]]. Al-Nabi Rubin students used to attend school in the nearby village of [[Tarbikha]]. ==History== In the late nineteenth century, Al-Nabi Rubin was described as a small village located on a hilltop, around a tomb, or "Neby". There were about 90 [[Muslim]] villagers. Arable land, [[Common fig|fig]] and [[olive]] trees surrounded the village. Two [[cistern]]s and a "birket" was also near.<ref>Survey of Western Palestine, 1881, I, [http://www.archive.org/stream/surveyofwesternp01conduoft#page/149/mode/1up p.149].</ref> ===1948, and afterwards=== [[Image:Saasaa 1948.jpg|250px|left|thumb|IDF soldiers during Operation Hiram, as photographed in [[Sa'sa']] on 30 October 1948]] The village was captured by [[Israel]] as a result of the [[Haganah]]'s offensive, [[Operation Hiram]] during the [[1948 Arab-Israeli War]] and was mostly destroyed with the exception of its shrine. Al-Nabi Rubin inhabitants were expelled to [[Lebanon]] in two waves, the aged and infirm were the last to depart when the IDF trucked them to the Lebanese border.<ref>Morris, Benny, (second edition 2004 third printing 2006) The Birth Of The Palestinian Refugee Problem Revisited, Cambridge University Press, ISBN 0-521-00967-7 pp 506-507</ref> A shrine thought to be dedicated to the prophet [[Rubin]] is the only original structure that remains on former village's lands.<ref>[http://www.palestineremembered.com/Acre/al-Nabi-Rubin/index.html al-Nabi Rubin: Town Statistics] from palestineremembered.com</ref> ==See also== *[[List of Arab towns and villages depopulated during the 1948 Palestinian exodus]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{Refbegin}} *[[Claude Reignier Conder|Conder, Claude Reignier]] and [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|H.H.
